result.execSummary:
On one or more charges in this case, Jacqueline J. Joles was found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. The defendant was found guilty of actually committing the crime(s) charged, but was also found not to be legally responsible under Wis. Stats. 971.165 for committing the crime(s) because of the defendant's mental condition. The legal effect of a finding of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is that the court must commit the defendant to the custody of the Department of Health and Family Services.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.action: Guilty but Not Guilty Due to Mental Disease/Defect

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty but Not Guilty Due to Mental Disease/Defect

Defendant Jacqueline J. Joles in court with attorney Jeremiah Wolfgang Meyer-O'Day.  Matthew C. Allen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Atty Meyer-O'Day has the conditional release plan as drafted by DHS, objection to #12 only.  Atty Allen addresses court - order for placement discussed and submitted for signing.  Court reviews conditions of proposed plan(s).  #12 is in regards to no out of state travel - Atty Meyer-O'Day addresses court and advises DA Nelson does not object to the defendant traveling to Sioux City, Iowa,  June 4 - July 5, 2017 and requests an order allowing this.  If this is not allowed, it was suggested that the defendant will withdraw the NGI plea and request probation with all the same conditions and allow for out of state travel.  State does not object to the Court authorizing travel while under committment/supervision of DHS.  Court will authorize the defendant's travel from 06/04/17-07/05/2017 to visit her husband in Iowa.  Atty Meyer-O'Day will prepare order; once this is submitted and signed, Court will sign further orders requested.
Tari spoke with Agent Schluter - she will send completed order for Judge Koehler's signature, but it won't be in until 5/18/2017.
of Brooke Schluter from LSS

Hearing on April 24, 2017 at 01:45 pm.

Appearances stated:  ADA Matt Allen for the State of Wisconsin, Atty. Jeremiah Meyer-O'Day for Jacqueline J. Joles.  Ct. hears from ADA Allen and Atty. Meyer-O'Day.  Ct. finds Ms. Joles not responsible by clear and convincing evidence Wis. Stat. Sec. 971.15(1); DHS to prepare Conditional Release Treatment Plan, suspend proceedings and reconvene in 21 days after formal commitment.  Ct. sets Hearing on conditional release for 4/24/2017 at 1:45 p.m.
Sentencing hearing on April 7, 2017 at 04:00 pm.

Defendant Jacqueline J. Joles in court with attorney Jeremiah Wolfgang Meyer-O'Day.  Matthew C. Allen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Report received by the Court.  NGI plea supported.  Request for time to consider options.   Factual pleas of no contest entered on all counts. Court verbally reviews charges/penalties with the defendant.  Defendant sworn by the Clerk.  Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights form - colloquy given.  Defendant freely, willingly, knowledgeably and intelligently enters into the plea agreement and joint recommendation.  Time limits waived for 14 day time limit.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for April 7, 2017 at 04:00 pm.
